utterances: Back in 1911, Yale explorer Hiram Bingham III used this town, high in the Andes, as his base camp to explore the ancient stone ruins of Machu Picchu.
Bingham introduced the site to the world through his articles for National Geographic magazine.
He returned twice and excavated thousands of artifacts -ceramics, tools, jewelry and human bones - with the consent of the Peruvian government.
Nearly a century ago, Peru set out to establish a new way of studying its artifacts and a new way of letting its artifacts move through the world.
Christopher Heaney is author of the book ""Cradle of Gold,"" about the life of Hiram Bingham.
He says as early as 1911, Peruvians were anxious to protect their cultural patrimony from looting.
They passed a law forbidding artifacts from leaving the country.
So in 1912 when Bingham came back, Peru offered Bingham a resolution under which the artifacts could leave to be studied by Yale.
It was a recognition of Yales scientific commitment.
But the artifacts will leave on just one condition, that they could be sent back whenever Peru asked.
And some did return, but most remained at Yales Peabody Museum.
The university said the artifacts had been sent to New Haven to be studied permanently.

Yale claimed title to the collection and insisted that under the laws of the day, finders of antiquities were allowed to keep them, that despite written correspondence in which Bingham acknowledges an obligation to return the objects.
Peruvian demands escalated about eight years ago, and in 2008, Peru sued in U.S.
federal court.
Yale countered with a motion to dismiss the case, saying the country had lost its right to the materials by waiting too long to ask for them.
Things really heated up about a month ago, when Peru launched an aggressive media campaign.
Peruvian president Alan Garcia led thousands of protestors through the streets of Lima, demanding that Yale send back the collection.
(Speaking foreign language).
Garcia asked President Obama to help resolve the standoff.
Peruvians even traveled to the Vatican and asked the Pope to intercede.
Byrne says if applications are being rejected, it's because there's something else missing.
Cynthia Caldero (ph).
says the whole process has worn her out.
In 2010, she built her little wooden home in an informal community, no title.
Maria blew it to the ground, and Caldero has been denied a repair grant four times.
She keeps the denial letters in a little black backpack.
(Speaking Spanish).
Denied, the letter says.
Can't prove ownership."" Caldero may appeal again.
The last month, a nonprofit repaired her little house using wood.
If FEMA eventually does approve her application, she said she'll replace the wood with concrete so it'll maybe survive the next hurricane.
Adrian Florido, NPR News, San Juan, Puerto Rico.
From NPR News, this is NEWS & NOTES.
I'm Ed Gordon.
Today, a look at the rising cost of fuel.
Crude oil prices have been soaring toward record levels, and that's putting serious pressure on many Americans.
NPR's Farai Chideya spoke with one independent businessman struggling to make ends meet while keeping his tank full.
(Soundbite buzzer; door closing)
So we're in an industrial part of downtown Los Angeles with Reginald Lampley(ph).
He's given us a little sense of gas prices based on his business.
What I do for a living, I do mobile auto detailing.
I service clients at their home or their job, wash their car and detail their car for them so they don't have to go to a car wash.
You've got a van.
It's a large passenger van.
It's got your supplies in it.
So you travel all around the city?
Yes, I do.
I travel to Santa Monica, downtown LA, Long Beach, Ventura, Pasadena.
And how much do you pay for gas each week?
Well, in the run of a week, I'm up to about 250 now, maybe 260.
Two hundred and fifty dollars?
Yup.
And where does that money come from that you do--are you charging more money now to your customers because gas prices have done up?
Oh, no, I'm not charging them.
They're feeling the same bite I'm feeling.
They have to travel to and from work also, so I'm not charging my customers any extra money just for their car washes anymore.
And what do you think about these prices?
Outrageous!
A man living like me can't--is having a hard time.
That's $250, almost a thousand dollars a month in gas.
What are you doing?
Are you cutting back on some things in your personal life with your family?
Are you trying to work extra jobs?
What are you doing now that the gas prices are cutting into your profits?
Well, I'm cutting back on a lot of my extra activities, my personal activities, as far as like going roller-skating or going out to the movies, go-kart racing.
So tell us a little bit about your family.
You've got kids, right?
Ah, yeah, I've got four kids.
I have two young adults and two teen-agers.
And I bet they want you to burn up your gas taking them places?
They--yeah, they burn up my gas every day.
`Daddy, can we go here?
Daddy, can we all go and do this?
No. I still pick my kids up.
I still take them places.
And I just have to suck it up.
What are you going to do if the gas prices stay this high?
What's going to happen to your business?
Ooh, probably have to take a second job just to make ends meet and go from there, try and advertise a little bit more and get some more customers.
Thanks, Reginald.
You're welcome.
Farai Chideya, NPR News.
I'm Ari Shapiro with news of big mergers in the health care industry.
The giant insurance company Cigna is buying Express Scripts, which administers prescription drug insurance plans for millions of Americans.
That deal is worth $67 billion.
And it comes just about three months after CVS said it plans to buy Aetna.
This is part of a wave of mergers that could change how health care is delivered and paid for.
So we're going to talk about what's happening with NPR health policy correspondent Alison Kodjak.
Hi, Alison.
Hey, Ari.
Cigna plus Express Scripts equals what?
What does this combined company look like?
Well, like, to get it really basic, Cigna's an insurance company.
So it pays for your doctor's appointments, your hospital visits, your lab tests.
And Express Scripts is what's called a pharmacy benefit manager.
And so they take care of your prescription drug insurance.
So the key here is that the companies don't do the same thing.
So when they merge - if it's approved - they're going to offer a different services - a larger bunch of services in one company.
And so at least experts who worry about things like antitrust say this probably won't face the antitrust problems that a couple of years ago when big insurance companies tried to merge did.
So if this merger does go through, and the CVS-Aetna merger also goes through, you're going to have these much bigger, more integrated companies.
What will that mean for health care consumers?
Well, a lot of people say, you know, it could be really good for consumers.
Of course, there are a lot of caveats.
You know, we don't know how it's going to play out and exactly what they're going to do with this big powerful company.
But some of the experts I talked to say they could work because it makes the interests of the insurer align with the interest of the people who pay for your prescription drugs.
And so they both want to spend less money.
And to do that, they really have to keep you healthier.
So by putting them together, it could be better for patients.
Can you give us an example?
Well, first of all, tell us the story of this particular ship.
And that's not far from where you are right now.
Yale anthropology professor Richard Burger oversees the Machu Picchu collection and was on the negotiating team.
He says reaching an agreement served everyones interest.
The presidency of Alan Garcia is coming to an end, and I think hed like to resolve this before he leaves office.
And I also think the two sides realize that even though there are legal proceedings, that those proceedings probably wont satisfy either side no matter what ruling the judge gives.
Within days, the two sides signed a memorandum of understanding, or MOU.
Peruvian foreign minister Jose Garcia Belaunde says the leadership and direct intervention by Yales president was crucial.
Its the first time that we have contact with the president of the university.
Before that, we had been negotiating with lawyers and officers of the university.
